author: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter
title: A.I.’s Inroads in Publishing Touch Off Fear, and Creativity
description: The technology has the potential to affect nearly every aspect of how books are produced — even the act of writing itself.
content: The arrival of Amazon reshaped the retail landscape for books. The rise of e-books threatened the printed word. And the boom in self publishing gave writers a path to success that left out traditional publishing houses. Each time, the book business was able to adapt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Easterling
title: Astros Pitcher Faces the Minimum in No-Hitter Against Cleveland
description: Framber Valdez allowed one walk, and had that runner erased on a double-play in a dominant effort against the Guardians.
content: Framber Valdez of the Houston Astros threw the second solo no-hitter of the season on Tuesday, shutting down the Cleveland Guardians in a 2-0 win Tuesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Part Thriller, Part Whodunit: The Trump Indictment Is a Must-Read
description: The document isn’t a pleasant read, but it’s surprisingly readable.
content: The federal indictment issued this week against Donald Trump for his efforts to steal the 2020 presidential election has a literary quality to it. It reads like a movie script.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Before There Was Pee-wee, There Was Pinky
description: Paul Reubens’s trademark style took plenty of its inspiration from a performer long forgotten.
content: Origin stories are notoriously hard to pin down in the humor business, since only the creator knows where the joke began. Lineages, on the other hand, are a lot easier to trace. The comedian Paul Reubens, a.k.a. Pee-wee Herman, who died this week of cancer at 70, belongs to a long line of American comics stretching back to the golden age of television and, beyond it, to the early days of vaudeville and burlesque.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Ukraine Says Russia Targeted Kyiv With Overnight Drone Attacks
description: Moscow launched at least 10 drones at the city, with an administrative building among those damaged by debris from interceptions, local officials said.
content: Russia attacked the Ukrainian capital, Kyiv, with at least 10 drones overnight, damaging a multistory administrative tower and other buildings, Ukrainian officials said on Wednesday, as Moscow kept up the pressure on metropolitan centers far from the front lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper and Brooks Barnes
title: How ESPN Went From Disney’s Financial Engine to Its Problem
description: The sports juggernaut continues to earn billions of dollars for Disney, but profits are down and opportunities for growth have dwindled.
content: ESPN has been Disney’s financial engine for nearly 30 years, powering the company through recessions, box office wipeouts and the pandemic. It was ESPN money that helped Disney pay for acquisitions — Marvel, Lucasfilm, Pixar, 21st Century Fox — and build a streaming service, transforming itself into a colossus and perhaps traditional media’s best hope of surviving Silicon Valley’s incursion into entertainment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Peach Cobbler as You’ve Never Seen It
description: Melissa Clark flips the classic on its head, letting flaky biscuits serve as a base for juicy, caramelized peaches.
content: Whether it’s a fancy apple tarte Tatin, a robust pineapple-ringed upside-down cake or a saucy flan, there’s something thrilling and suspenseful about turning your homemade dessert on its head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Where the Republican Candidates Stand on the Trump Indictments
description: Former President Donald J. Trump has cast the many charges against him as politically motivated and legally meritless — and most of the Republicans looking to beat him have gone along.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump faces an expanding collection of felony charges: There’s the indictment in New York City over hush payments to a pornographic actress, plus a federal indictment over his retention of classified documents, plus another federal indictment over his attempts to overturn the 2020 election, which culminated in his supporters’ storming the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. There’s an investigation into election interference in Georgia, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: A Third Trump Indictment, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Jury in Pittsburgh Synagogue Trial Condemns Gunman to Death
description: The verdict, after nearly 10 hours of deliberations, was met with a mix of solemnity, gratitude and relief among the survivors and families of those killed in the 2018 attack.
content: Nearly every morning for three months, family members and survivors quietly gathered in a federal courtroom in Pittsburgh. They listened to witnesses recount the terror of the morning nearly five years ago when a gunman murdered 11 worshipers in their synagogue, and to witnesses who tried to explain what drove the man to commit such horror.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Stylish (but Stress-Free) Summer Dinner Party
description: Mix and match recipes from our NYT Cooking columnists: Yewande Komolafe’s coconut-dill salmon, Eric Kim’s grilled chops with plum BBQ sauce, Genevieve Ko’s deeply purple blueberry crisp.
content: Are summer dinner parties more relaxed than their winter counterparts? I suppose it depends on the cook and the crowd. All the brightly colored produce and fresh herbs from the planter box make me want to cook up a gorgeous feast to share with friends, but the wearying heat and vacation vibes mean I don’t want to work very hard to get there. Relatable?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Leprosy May Be Endemic in Central Florida, Scientists Report
description: Still, there are fewer than 200 cases nationally each year, and the numbers have fallen significantly from the peak decades ago.
content: Leprosy, a fearsome scourge of ancient civilizations, may have become a permanent fixture in Florida, according to a new study.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: How Four Female Philosophers Responded to a Dire Decade
description: “The Visionaries,” by Wolfram Eilenberger, examines the divergent theories of self and other developed in a time of crisis by Hannah Arendt, Simone de Beauvoir, Ayn Rand and Simone Weil.
content: If hell is other people, then so, too, is this world. Accepting the reality of others can take time. During a general strike in France in 1934, Simone de Beauvoir felt no particular urge to stand in solidarity with workers, including her colleagues at the lycée where she was teaching. “The existence of Otherness remained a danger to me,” she later recalled. “Around us other people circled, pleasant, odious or ridiculous: They had no eyes with which to observe me. I alone could see.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Safak Timur, Ivan Nechepurenko and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Putin Speaks With Erdogan for 1st Time Since Russia Canceled Grain Deal
description: The Turkish president urged a resumption of the agreement that allowed Ukraine to ship grain through the Black Sea, and called on both Russia and Ukraine not to escalate tensions.
content: Turkey’s president has called on Russia and Ukraine to avoid escalating their conflict and urged the resumption of a deal that had enabled Ukraine to export its grain across the Black Sea, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s office said on Wednesday after he spoke by telephone with his Russian counterpart, Vladimir V. Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Used to Be
description: Barbara Lin takes us back the way we came.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: 2nd Supermoon of the Year Illuminates the Night Sky Around the World
description: On Tuesday night, the Sturgeon Moon was visible from Greece to Brazil. Two more supermoons are expected this year: one in late August and the other in September.
content: The second supermoon of this year — the Sturgeon Moon — left stargazers awed on Tuesday night, drawing large crowds in parts of Europe, the Americas and Asia, and once again piquing interest in the night sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The Long, Perilous Road Ahead for Donald Trump
description: Also, U.S.-trained troops stumble in Ukraine. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: Before this year, no American president had ever been arraigned on federal criminal charges. Tomorrow, when Donald Trump is set to appear in federal court in Washington and plead not guilty to accusations that he attempted to overturn the 2020 election, it would happen for the second time in two months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Trump Jan. 6 Indictment Relies Heavily on House Panel’s Work
description: The special House committee that investigated the attack on the Capitol created the road map for the charges against the former president.
content: In taking the monumental step of charging a former president with attempting to steal an American election, Jack Smith, the Justice Department special counsel, relied on an extraordinary narrative, but one the country knew well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: A President Accused of Betraying His Country
description: The criminal justice system of the United States has never seen an indictment of this magnitude, in which a former president is accused of defrauding his country.
content: Of all the ways that Donald Trump desecrated his office as president, the gravest — as outlined in extraordinary detail in the criminal indictment issued against him on Tuesday — was his attempt to undermine the Constitution and overturn the results of the 2020 election, hoping to stay in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adrian Eli René and Airea D. Matthews
title: The Magical Space Where Fun Is Every Child’s Birthright
description: For kids in Philadelphia, the city’s recreation centers open a world of possibilities.
content: Where can our children safely play?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: ‘Barbenheimer’ Isn’t a Contest. But if It Were, Which Film Would Win?
description: It’s been an epic matchup, but it’s time to declare a victor. We devised nine super-scientific tests to determine whether “Barbie” or “Oppenheimer” rules.
content: The simultaneous release of “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” captured the pop-cultural imagination because before we had seen either film, it was hard to imagine two features that occupied such distinctly different lanes. But now that audiences have sampled Greta Gerwig’s colorful Mattel comedy and Christopher Nolan’s weighty drama about J. Robert Oppenheimer, the so-called father of the atomic bomb, it’s become clear that for all their tonal differences, each film is a one-of-a-kind auteurist blockbuster pondering some pretty meaty existential questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The U.S. Is Finally Trying to Fix Its Money-Laundering Problem
description: We’re arguably the world capital for hiding ill-gotten gains — but maybe not for much longer.
content: On Dec. 9, 2021, at the inaugural Summit for Democracy, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen made a stunning admission: Her country had become the world’s most sought-after shelter for criminals’ money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: contrail
description: This word has appeared in three articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word contrail has appeared in three articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 19 in “Could Air Someday Power Your Flight? Airlines Are Betting on It” by Paige McClanahan:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Top Editor at The Atlantic Will Moderate ‘Washington Week’
description: The Atlantic will co-produce the show, which will be renamed “Washington Week With The Atlantic.” The publication will cover some of the costs and help sell sponsorships.
content: “PBS NewsHour” announced Wednesday that Jeffrey Goldberg, the editor in chief of The Atlantic, would be the next moderator of “Washington Week,” the Friday evening public affairs show that is a staple among policymakers in the nation’s capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Xi’s Surprise Shake-Up Exposes Problems at Top of China’s Nuclear Force
description: The Chinese leader’s replacement of two commanders has fanned speculation about corruption or failings in the force that manages China’s nuclear missiles.
content: In the years since China’s leader, Xi Jinping, transformed the People’s Liberation Army, one of his crowning creations has been the Rocket Force, the custodian of China’s expanding nuclear arsenal. The force, with its array of missiles and launch silos, embodied Mr. Xi’s ambitions to elevate his country as a respected, and feared, great power ready to counter American supremacy in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison and Alan Rappeport
title: Debt Downgrade, Driven by Partisanship, Is Unlikely to Deter Borrowing
description: Fitch’s credit-rating decision stemmed from concerns about America’s ability to govern itself, along with the nation’s growing debt load.
content: The downgrade of the United States’ debt by a major ratings firm is a damning indictment of the country’s fractious politics and a blot on its financial record that is unlikely to be quickly erased. But many investors and analysts say it won’t affect the government’s ability to keep borrowing money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Janie Osborne
title: A Slice of Big Sky Country You Won’t See on ‘Yellowstone’
description: In Montana, a stretch of U.S. Highway 2 known as the Hi-Line is colored by grain elevators, railroad cars and century-old homesteading remnants.
content: Recently, western Montana and cities like Bozeman are experiencing a surge in popularity because of the wildly successful drama “Yellowstone” and its prequels “1883” and “1923.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: How Rudy Giuliani Became Co-Conspirator 1
description: Referred to as “Co-Conspirator 1” in the indictment of Donald Trump, the former prosecutor, mayor and presidential lawyer faces an uncertain legal future.
content: Rudolph W. Giuliani is Co-Conspirator 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
title: ‘Divided Loyalties’ May Afflict Lawyer in Mar-a-Lago Case, Prosecutors Say
description: Prosecutors questioned whether Stanley Woodward Jr. could defend Walt Nauta while also representing Trump employees who might take the stand against Mr. Nauta.
content: The special counsel Jack Smith has requested a hearing to determine if a lawyer representing one of former President Donald J. Trump’s co-defendants, Walt Nauta, has “divided loyalties” by simultaneously working for three witnesses who could be called to testify at a trial in the case involving classified documents at Mar-a-Lago, according to a motion filed on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Anna Betts and Jon Moss
title: A Painful Process, Survivors Say, but the Only Way to Ensure Justice for Victims
description: Some people expressed firm approval of the death sentence or acceptance that the jury had reached the right decision, while others were disappointed at the outcome.
content: Over nearly five years, Rabbi Doris Dyen has listened to countless horror stories from those who, like her, survived the mass shooting that killed 11 people at a Pittsburgh synagogue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: ‘Huberman Husbands,’ ‘Bro Diets’ and the ‘Masculine’ Branding of Fitness Culture
description: Men are increasingly enthusiastic about comparing notes on health regimens.
content: It started with a suspicious green sludge at the bottom of our drinking glasses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Teens Are Dying on E-Bikes. Should California Regulate Them?
description: Electric bicycles are convenient, affordable and popular, but on busy roads built for cars, their speed can be dangerous, especially for young riders.
content: In late June, Encinitas, a beach town in north San Diego County, declared a state of emergency for what initially seemed to be a surprising reason: e-bike safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nguyễn Phan Quế Mai
title: Read Your Way Through Hanoi
description: Hanoi, long a city of storytellers, has been devastated and reborn time and time again. Nguyễn Phan Quế Mai guides readers through the literature that has played a part in that renewal.
content: Hanoi has always been a city of tales and legends. Its ancient name, Thang Long, which means “the Rising Dragon,” comes from a tale about Emperor Ly Thai To witnessing a golden dragon ascending when he moved the capital here in 1010. The city is now the heartland of Vietnamese literature — home to many of our finest writers, literary festivals and book fairs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Stella Tan, Rikki Novetsky, Will Reid, Rachel Quester, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: The Charges Against Trump for Conspiring to Overturn the Election
description: The former president was charged with four counts in connection with efforts to subvert the will of voters in 2020.
content: On Tuesday afternoon, the special counsel Jack Smith filed criminal charges against former President Donald Trump over his wide-ranging attempt to overthrow the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 2, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Aug. 2, 2023.
content: The “Headline in History” article on Saturday referred imprecisely to Bela Lugosi’s film appearances. He starred in “Dracula” in 1931 and “White Zombie” in 1932; he did not go on to play Dracula after his appearance in “White Zombie.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Julia Botero, Christina Djossa, Elyssa Dudley, Hans Buetow, Jen Poyant, Sara Sarasohn, Sophia Lanman, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Rowan Niemisto
title: I Needed David Schwimmer’s Help
description: When her aunt died by suicide, Samantha Joseph went on a yearslong quest to understand why it happened. That search eventually led her to a moving conversation with the “Friends” actor.
content: Samantha Joseph’s childhood was scattered with golden trips to California to visit her Aunt Gail. Aunt Gail was the cool aunt. She worked in Hollywood and befriended actors like Robin Williams, Mayim Bialik and the cast of “Friends.” And yet she was still relatable (she’d get on the floor and play like a kid).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: What if We’re the Bad Guys Here?
description: How the modern meritocracy made Trump inevitable.
content: Donald Trump seems to get indicted on a weekly basis. Yet he is utterly dominating his Republican rivals in the polls, and he is tied with Joe Biden in the general election surveys. Trump’s poll numbers are stronger against Biden now than at any time in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: This Ancient Whale May Have Been the Heaviest Animal Ever
description: Perucetus drifted through shallow seas like a gigantic manatee, scientists suspect.
content: Paleontologists on Wednesday unveiled the fossilized bones of one of the strangest whales in history. The 39-million-year-old leviathan, called Perucetus, may have weighed about 200 tons, as much as a blue whale — by far the heaviest animal known, until now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By B.D. McClay
title: What I Saw When I Looked Inside My Own Body
description: Modern medicine is constantly showing us our guts and bones. Why doesn’t it feel more profound?
content: It wasn’t that I thought medical imaging was simple, precisely. I understood that a real human body is complicated — that the anatomy textbooks were the map, not the territory. I understood that the plastic dummy with its removable organs was a model, not an exact representation; that the brightly colored images hanging in the doctor’s office were not photographs; that the episode of “The Magic School Bus” in which the class travels through Arnold’s digestive system was not a documentary. Still, what I did not anticipate was that when confronted with an image of my own body — the product of the rotating series of X-rays known as a CT scan — I wouldn’t recognize it at all. I don’t mean as myself, but as anything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Trump Indicted, Again
description: The latest indictment of Trump raises issues at the core of American democracy.
content: The two previous indictments of Donald Trump focused on his personal conduct, one involving a sex scandal and the other his handling of classified documents. Yesterday’s indictment is different. It involves arguably the most central issue in a democracy: an attempt to subvert an American election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anakwa Dwamena
title: A Rich Stranger Wants to Give You All His Money. There’s a Catch.
description: In “Anansi’s Gold,” Yepoka Yeebo delves into the origins of a venerable scam — and the man who got away with it for decades.
content: Stop me if you’ve heard this one: A stranger needs to retrieve money stuck in a bank. But in order to access these vast sums, he needs travel fare. And to meet this and other administrative costs necessary to unlocking this fortune, would you kindly help him with a little investment? You will be duly rewarded for your generosity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Dines With Fox News Executives After Learning of Third Indictment
description: The Fox leaders appealed to the former president to participate in the first G.O.P. debate, which is being hosted by the network.
content: Shortly after learning he was being indicted a third time, former President Donald J. Trump had a private dinner with the top leadership at Fox News as they lobbied him to attend the first Republican presidential primary debate this month, three people familiar with the event said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Loudin
title: Dive Into an Open-Water Workout
description: Swimming in a lake or the ocean is an exhilarating alternative to your usual pool routine. Here’s how to get started.
content: For many, the idea of swimming in open water is unnerving. The waves, tides and deep waters often prevent people from venturing out. But for those who do, it’s a fun and exhilarating challenge that’s good for your body and mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: Review: An American Opera Gets the Attention It Needs Abroad
description: Anthony Braxton’s “Trillium X,” part of a sweeping cycle of operas that began in the 1980s, finally premiered in Prague.
content: Anyone bold enough to take command of a pirate ship should also be prepared for strife. Cannon battles? Frustrated crew members? All part of the job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French and Vishakha Darbha
title: The Far-Reaching Consequences of the Latest Trump Indictment
description: David French on why the new charges get to the “heart of one of the most malicious conspiracies in American history.”
content: The latest charges against Donald Trump amount to “the most consequential of all the indictments filed so far,” the Opinion columnist David French argues in this audio essay. On Tuesday, the former president was indicted on four federal counts related to his efforts to overturn the 2020 election, efforts that were part of what French calls “one of the most malicious conspiracies in American history.” Despite this, the case, which hinges on proving Trump’s intent, may not be a slam dunk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salamishah Tillet
title: Why Nina Simone Was Always Ahead of Her Time
description: A recently unearthed live version of “Blues for Mama,” written by Simone and Abbey Lincoln in the 1960s, took on domestic abuse in a momentous way.
content: Nina Simone was always ahead of her time. And in the mid-1960s she found a fellow musical innovator and ideal feminist collaborator in the jazz vocalist Abbey Lincoln, whom she teamed up with to write the song “Blues for Mama.” When Simone performed it at the Newport Jazz Festival in 1966, she introduced it as “a gutbucket blues.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Lois Libien, Who Found a Readership With Household Tips, Dies at 87
description: As a journalist she covered issues affecting women, then turned to writing about housekeeping in handbooks and a syndicated newspaper column.
content: Lois Libien, who broke ground in the 1960s as a female journalist in a largely male field but who attracted her widest readership by providing household hints in books and a nationally syndicated newspaper column, died on July 25 in River Vale, N.J. She was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Swan and Luke Broadwater
title: Messages Point to Identity of Co-Conspirator 6 in Trump Indictment
description: An email sent by Boris Epshteyn, an adviser to the Trump campaign, matches the description of an email that the indictment attributed to one of six unnamed co-conspirators.
content: The indictment of former President Donald J. Trump in connection with his efforts to retain power after his 2020 election loss left a number of unanswered questions, among them: Who is Co-Conspirator 6?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: What happens to the Tree of Life synagogue building after the trial?
description: The congregation intends top keep using the facility for worship, while also transforming it into a place of commemoration.
content: Since the morning in October 2018 when a gunman killed 11 worshipers at the Tree of Life synagogue in Pittsburgh, the somber building complex has been by turns a crime scene, a place of mourning and the subject of long, emotional discussions about its future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pavin Chachavalpongpun
title: Everybody Won in Thailand’s Election, Except the Voters
description: The royalist establishment is denying the will of the people once again.
content: For a brief time this summer, it seemed that Thailand might finally be on the cusp of truly representative government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and John Koblin
title: Hollywood Studios Signal New Strategy by Talking With Writers
description: The actors’ union has historically been more willing to negotiate, but when Fran Drescher took a hard line as its leader, executives shifted their focus to the other striking guild.
content: When the Writers Guild of America told its members on Tuesday night that movie and television studios had asked for “a meeting this Friday to discuss negotiations,” it was the first sign of movement in a stalemate that had begun in early May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: An Aging Pope Francis Looks to ‘Youth Day’ to Energize Church’s Future
description: The pope will preside over a gathering of young people from around the world, mindful that the changes he has initiated in the Roman Catholic Church will depend on them.
content: Pope Francis, deep into his 80s, slowed by illness and aware that his window for bringing lasting change to the Roman Catholic Church is closing, arrived in Portugal on Wednesday for a weeklong meeting of the world’s young Catholics, in whose hands will rest the ultimate success or failure of his vision for a more pastoral and inclusive faith.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Rogers
title: ‘Sex Is a Huge Part of a Character’s Life.’ Especially in ‘Passages.’
description: The three stars of Ira Sachs’ new movie — Franz Rogowski, Ben Whishaw and Adèle Exarchopoulos — discuss the graphic film’s approach to sexuality and intimacy.
content: When Ira Sachs’ new movie “Passages” premiered at the Sundance Film Festival earlier this year, critics couldn’t stop talking about the sex scenes. The movie, a drama set in Paris about a film director who leaves his longtime boyfriend for a young woman, featured an all-star European art-house cast — Franz Rogowski (“Transit,” “Great Freedom”), Ben Whishaw (“The Lobster,” “Little Joe”) and Adèle Exarchopoulos (“Blue is the Warmest Color”) — negotiating infidelity and betrayal. And having graphic sex.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is This the Moment of Reckoning for Donald Trump?
description: Readers discuss the latest charges against the former president. Also: The awnings of New York; factory farming.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Two spots are up for grabs in Group F with three teams tightly chasing them.
description: Brazil needs to win this match to avoid elimination, because it can’t count on Panama, the worst team in the group, to beat France. But Jamaica has its sights set on the round of 16, too, and it can advance with a win or a draw.
content: Brazil needs to win this match to avoid elimination, because it can’t count on Panama, the worst team in the group, to beat France. But Jamaica has its sights set on the round of 16, too, and it can advance with a win or a draw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Washington
title: The Best Chilaquiles You’ve Ever Had
description: The perfect breakfast of fried corn tortillas in salsa is always the one you just ate. This recipe is no exception.
content: It’s tough to paint a picture of my first chilaquiles plate, but I’ll try: simmering green salsa on a pastel dish, covering crispy tortilla chips cracking like eggshells against a fork — and also a runny egg, with handfuls of herbs and entirely too much queso fresco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: Federal Appeals Court Further Limits Abortion Access on Guam
description: The court ruled that women seeking abortion pills must first see a doctor in person. The catch: The nearest abortion doctor is an eight-hour flight away.
content: A federal appeals court ruled late Tuesday that women on the American territory of Guam who are seeking medication abortion must first have an in-person consultation with a doctor, which is likely to make access to the procedure on the remote island even more difficult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Election Charges Set Up Clash of Lies Versus Free Speech
description: The indictment of former President Donald J. Trump over his efforts to retain power accuses him of conspiracies built on knowing falsehoods. His supporters say he is protected by the First Amendment.
content: Running through the indictment charging former President Donald J. Trump with conspiring to overturn the 2020 election was a consistent theme: He is an inveterate and knowing liar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Tired of Dating Apps, Some Turn to ‘Date-Me Docs’
description: Writers of the online text profiles, which can read like 1,000-word versions of the personal ads of yore, hope for a more meaningful connection than a swipe might allow.
content: After going through a breakup last year, Connie Li, a software engineer, rejoined the dating apps, ready to dip her toe in the water again. But many of the men who reached out to her seemed to just want something casual, so she tried something new.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis and Emma Goldberg
title: Frontline Workers: How Has Your Commute Changed During the Pandemic?
description: If you have never had the option to work from home because your job must be done in person, tell us how your commute has shifted over the past three years.
content: Cities and workplaces have been upended since the pandemic began. Some people moved from cities to suburbs. Stores and restaurants moved out of busy downtown areas. Train and bus schedules shifted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo
title: In Focus, an Actors’ Strike and Hollywood’s Future
description: Lights. Camera. Action? Brooks Barnes, who covers the entertainment business, discussed the state of film and television amid an industrywide shutdown.
content: It was around 1 a.m. one Thursday last month when Brooks Barnes received the email he’d been waiting up for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: The N.B.A. and Its Owners Fight for Change. But Not Necessarily the Same Change.
description: The league embraces progressive causes supported by players. But some team owners pull in the opposite direction, as apparent in the Orlando Magic’s donation to Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida.
content: In June 2022, on the same day the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, Adam Silver, the N.B.A. commissioner, released a statement jointly with the W.N.B.A.’s commissioner, Cathy Engelbert.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Ormont Blumberg
title: Striking Actors Are Turning to Cameo for Extra Cash
description: Others are using the service, through which fans can pay for personalized videos, to engage with followers while not publicly promoting work.
content: On July 24 Cheyenne Jackson, an actor, posted a photo on Instagram that showed him shirtless, with glistening abs, veiny arms and his lips parted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Bishop Accused of Abuse Gets Married After Bid to Quit Church Is Denied
description: Emeritus Bishop Howard Hubbard of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Albany, N.Y., said he had married a woman after the Vatican declined his request to leave the clergy.
content: A retired Roman Catholic bishop in upstate New York who is a defendant in several sexual misconduct lawsuits said on Tuesday that he had recently married a woman after the Vatican denied his request to leave the clergy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa and Leanne Abraham
title: A Look at How Much Less Antarctic Sea Ice There Is This Year
description: It’s winter in Antarctica, when sea ice cover typically grows. But this year’s sea ice is way behind, reaching record lows with implications for the planet.
content: It’s winter in the Southern Hemisphere, when ice typically forms around Antarctica. But this year, that growth has been stunted, hitting a record low by a wide margin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.2 Million Homes in Vermont, New York and Ohio
description: A saltbox house with an attached 1830 barn in Hartland, a two-bedroom condominium in a 1914 building in Brooklyn and a Tudor Revival house in Akron.
content: This property is near Quechee State Park, where hiking trails offer sweeping views of the rural landscape. It is a 10-minute drive from a public library, a farmers’ market and a diner in the center of town. More shopping and dining options are in Woodstock, Vt., about 20 minutes away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Alan Roland, 93, Psychoanalyst Who Cautioned Against Western Bias, Dies
description: In “In Search of Self” and other books, he emphasized the role of cultural influences in a patient’s life.
content: Alan Roland, who brought new insights to psychoanalysis by calling out a Western bias in much of the field and factoring in differences in culture and upbringing among patients, died on July 22 at his home in Monterey, Mass. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: He Spent Decades Collecting Presidential Signatures. Then Lost Them in an Instant.
description: Carl Sferrazza Anthony, a historian, had collected the signatures of eight presidents and eight first ladies on an engraved card. He lost it in Washington last week.
content: The last time Carl Sferrazza Anthony saw what he calls the most valuable thing he owns, he was sitting at a corner table at a cafe in Washington, waiting for his udon noodle soup to arrive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Streep and Clooney Lead Donation Campaign for Striking Actors
description: The stars, joined by celebrities like Matt Damon and Oprah Winfrey, helped raise more than $15 million over the past three weeks.
content: Hollywood actors have now been on strike for nearly three weeks. They have walked picket lines in broiling heat, orchestrated noisy rallies and flooded social media with cris de coeur. Harrison Ford’s stunt double lit himself on fire (safely) at a protest in Georgia. The president of the actors’ union, Fran Drescher, spoke on Tuesday about “greed-driven” studios at a New York City Council meeting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: Switched at Birth, Two Canadians Discover Their Roots at 67
description: Two Canadian men who were switched at birth to families of different ethnicities are now questioning who they really are and learning how racial heritage shapes identities.
content: Richard Beauvais’s identity began unraveling two years ago, after one of his daughters became interested in his ancestry. She wanted to learn more about his Indigenous roots — she was even considering getting an Indigenous tattoo — and urged him to take an at-home DNA test. Mr. Beauvais, then 65, had spent a lifetime describing himself as “half French, half Indian,” or Métis, and he had grown up with his grandparents in a log house in a Métis settlement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliette Guéron-Gabrielle and Jenny Gross
title: Paris Bookstalls Are Told to Relocate During Next Year’s Olympics
description: The “bouquinistes” along the River Seine have objected after being told that most of them will have to move temporarily for security reasons.
content: The open-air bookstalls that line the River Seine are as symbolic of Paris as the Louvre or the Arc de Triomphe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Emile Ducke
title: Under Fire and Understaffed: The Fight to Save Ukraine’s Wounded
description: Positioned close to the front lines, temporary medical posts are a critical lifeline for the constant inflow of soldiers hurt in the counteroffensive.
content: A commotion sounded at the entrance of the building, and a shout went up. Soldiers carried in two men on stretchers, one his lined face taut in a grimace, a third, with bloodstained pants, following behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan
title: Four Takeaways From the Trump Indictment
description: The indictment of the former president for trying to subvert democracy was issued by a federal grand jury in the District of Columbia. It’s the third set of charges that he faces.
content: Jack Smith made only his second televised appearance as special counsel on Tuesday to explain his decision to charge former President Donald J. Trump with leading a conspiracy to overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alia Malek
title: Can a Rapper Change Italy’s Mind About Migrants?
description: As the country’s right-wing government takes a hard line on Mediterranean immigration, the hip-hop artist Ghali has become a prominent voice of compassion.
content: In mid-March, weeks after a ship wrecked on Italy’s Calabrian coast, the waters of the Mediterranean Sea were still releasing ashore what remained: planks of wood, engine parts, children’s shoes, bodies. The season of drowning migrants had come early this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: In New York, One Team Is Lost and the Other Is Targeting 2025
description: The middling Yankees have no idea who they are. The Mets’ sell-off gives them a clearer identity.
content: The New York baseball teams spent more than $600 million, combined, on their payrolls this season. They ranked first (Mets) and second (Yankees) in the majors in spending, yet arrived at the trading deadline on Tuesday with more collective losses than wins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
title: Ukrainian Troops Trained by the West Stumble in Battle
description: Ukraine’s army has for now set aside U.S. fighting methods and reverted to tactics it knows best.
content: The first several weeks of Ukraine’s long-awaited counteroffensive have not been kind to the Ukrainian troops who were trained and armed by the United States and its allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Vjosa Isai
title: Justin Trudeau Separates From Wife, Sophie Grégoire
description: The Canadian prime minister and his wife have been married for 18 years and share three children.
content: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada announced on Wednesday that he and his wife, Sophie Grégoire Trudeau, had separated after 18 years of marriage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast (Deluxe): Our Favorite Albums of the Year So Far
description: Peso Pluma, Ice Spice, Skrillex, 100 gecs and more.
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on their favorite albums of 2023 so far:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Leily Nikounazar
title: Many Iranians Blame Creaky Power Grid and Gas Shortage for Sudden Holiday
description: The government in Tehran cited “unprecedented” heat when it ordered a two-day shutdown to protect health and conserve energy, but many residents were not buying it.
content: When the government in Iran ordered the nation to shut down for two days starting on Wednesday to conserve energy and protect public health because of “unprecedented” broiling summer heat, Iranians and experts alike quickly discerned another, unspoken reason for the enforced holiday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: ‘Kill the Boer’ Song Fuels Backlash in South Africa and U.S.
description: Right-wing commenters claim that an old anti-apartheid chant is a call to anti-white violence, but historians and the left-wing politician who embraces it say it should not be taken literally.
content: The political rally was winding down when the brash leader of a leftist South African party grabbed the microphone and began to stomp and chant. Thousands of supporters joined in, and when he reached the climax, they pointed their fingers in the air like guns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Iverson
title: Easy Mode: Clues for Aug. 4
description: Get some help on the Friday crossword puzzle.
content: Friday crosswords are among the hardest of the week. They are themeless, which means you can’t rely on that extra level of context to solve the puzzle, and the clues are written with a higher level of wit and wordplay. We know this can be daunting for newer solvers. If you need a little hint to unlock the puzzle, we’ve provided easy clues you can use. We recommend ctrl + f the number of the clue you’re looking for. You can also play a digital version of this puzzle with easy clues by signing up for our Easy Mode newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Annie Karni
title: Report of Shooter Panics Capitol Hill, but Police Find Nothing
description: After an urgent search on a quiet day at the Capitol, the police said the threat report might have been a “bogus call.”
content: The U.S. Capitol Police said late Wednesday afternoon that Capitol Hill was clear of a security threat that had briefly prompted a manhunt, evacuations and panic inside Senate office buildings after a report of an active shooter that the police chief later suggested might have been the result of “a bogus call.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Crump
title: With ‘Talk to Me,’ Directors Leap From Phone Screens to the Big Screen
description: The twin brothers Danny and Michael Philippou, who first gained popularity on YouTube, discuss their pivot to a theatrical release.
content: Ronald McDonald on a killing spree in a chicken joint. Harry Potter and Luke Skywalker going head-to-head with wands and light sabers. Cookie Monster eviscerating the Power Rangers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Martell
title: The Rays Plan to Keep Calm and Carry On
description: A red-hot start followed by a brutal July knocked Tampa Bay out of first place, but the Rays believe they are back on track.
content: The Tampa Bay Rays were the best team in Major League Baseball over the first three months of the season. In July, they were the second worst.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Spamalot’ Revival to Open on Broadway This Fall
description: The new production, directed by Josh Rhodes, had a brief run at the Kennedy Center in Washington in May. Casting has not yet been announced.
content: Make way for shrubbery: “Spamalot” is returning to Broadway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Miles Davis’s Electric Period
description: Navigate the trumpeter’s snaky, endless grooves with picks from Flying Lotus, Cindy Blackman Santana and Terence Blanchard, among other musicians, writers and critics.
content: For the past year, The New York Times has been asking musicians, writers and scholars to share the music they’d play for a friend to get them into jazz — one artist, instrument and subgenre at a time. We’ve covered Duke Ellington, Mary Lou Williams, New Orleans music, jazz vocalists and much more.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: For the U.S. Team, That Was a Close One
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, August 2, 2023.
content: “We’re just going to do a couple of Kumbayas, and we’ll be good.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Alan Feuer
title: Judge in Trump Jan. 6 Trial Is Known for Tough Capitol Riot Sentences
description: A judge with a liberal background and significant criminal trial experience, Tanya S. Chutkan swiftly ruled against the former president in his 2021 attempt to keep White House papers secret from the congressional inquiry.
content: When former President Donald J. Trump appears in court before Judge Tanya S. Chutkan on charges of conspiring to subvert American democracy, it will not be the first time she has dealt with high-profile questions related to Mr. Trump’s attempts to stay in power after losing the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: ‘We Are in a Five-Alarm Fire for Democracy’
description: Does free speech protect Trump’s election lies?
content: The indictment of Donald Trump on Tuesday on four counts stemming from his attempt to overturn the results of the 2020 election has reanimated a question legal scholars have long debated: Are Trump’s false claims that the election was stolen from him protected by the First Amendment?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Former Tour Dancers Accuse Lizzo of Harassment and Hostile Work Environment in Lawsuit
description: In a lawsuit filed Tuesday, three dancers claim that touring with the Grammy winner meant working in an “overtly sexual atmosphere” that subjected them to harassment.
content: Three of Lizzo’s former dancers filed a lawsuit against her on Tuesday in Los Angeles Superior Court, accusing the Grammy-winning singer and the captain of her dance team of creating a hostile work environment while performing concerts on her Special Tour this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: The Dance of Too-Hot Summer? Melt Into the Pinegrove Shuffle.
description: Garrett Lee, with an assist from DJ Khaled, fills a cultural hole with his floppy, hypnotic TikTok dance — still going strong in a sad, cathartic way.
content: The dancer, filmed on a residential street on a cloudy day, is an unassuming swan. Stepping forward on one foot, he lunges while his arms, as loose as cooked spaghetti, fling behind his rib cage. He rocks back and forth, brushing his other foot with a low kick to the front, his arms crossing at his chest. His wingspan — its billowy effect — is completely hypnotic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Roger Sprung, Banjo Virtuoso of N.Y.C. Folk Scene, Dies at 92
description: The “godfather” of progressive bluegrass, he grew up in New York, honed his skills in the mountains and flourished in Greenwich Village in the ’60s.
content: Roger Sprung, a banjo virtuoso and key figure in New York’s midcentury folk music revival, whose innovative picking and genre-mashing audacity earned him the unofficial title of the godfather of progressive bluegrass, died on July 22 at his home in Newtown, Conn. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Your Thursday Briefing: What’s Next for Trump?
description: Also, discovering the world’s heaviest animal.
content: Donald Trump’s indictment for trying to overturn the 2020 election has thrown the U.S. into uncharted territory ahead of the presidential vote next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Luke Broadwater and Ben Protess
title: Trump Indictment Leaves Alleged Co-Conspirators Facing Tough Choices
description: The special counsel’s decision not to charge six people said to have played critical roles in the effort to keep Donald Trump in office seemed to give them a chance to cooperate with prosecutors. Some appear to be unwilling.
content: By the time Jack Smith, the special counsel, was brought in to oversee the investigation of former President Donald J. Trump’s attempts to overturn the 2020 election, the inquiry had already focused for months on a group of lawyers close to Mr. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: City in Mexico Bans Performances of Songs With Misogynistic Lyrics
description: The city of Chihuahua said it would impose hefty fines on bands that perform songs with lyrics that “promote violence against women.”
content: Fed up with persistent violence, officials in the city of Chihuahua in northern Mexico approved a ban last week prohibiting musical acts from performing songs with lyrics that degrade women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elise Young
title: Four Killed in New Jersey House Fire
description: A discarded cigarette may have ignited the blaze, officials said. The victims included a baby, a 14-year-old and two adults.
content: A discarded cigarette may have ignited an accidental fire that killed four people, including a 4-month-old, at a New Jersey home on Tuesday, according to the Ocean County prosecutor’s office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: The Face of Israel’s Protests Is a Particle Physicist
description: Shikma Bressler, a mother of five who says her passion is life in the lab, has emerged as a symbol of the struggle against the government’s divisive judicial overhaul.
content: The particle physicist was sitting at a cafe in Tel Aviv when a young waitress rushed over, gushing at her in admiration. An older couple, a husband and wife, at the next table looked over at her with tears in their eyes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The Trial America Needs
description: The special counsel Jack Smith’s case against Donald Trump on charges related to the 2020 election will not be easy. But it is necessary.
content: At last. The federal criminal justice system is going to legal war against one of the most dishonest, malicious and damaging conspiracies in the history of the United States. Tuesday’s indictment of Donald Trump, brought by the special counsel Jack Smith’s office, is the culmination of a comprehensive effort to bring justice to those who attempted to overthrow the results of an American presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Fitch’s Warning About America’s Fiscal Future
description: A downgrade of the nation’s credit rating admonished Washington for persistent political fighting over federal spending. But the move drew sharp criticism.
content: Markets are pointing down this morning after Fitch Ratings downgraded the United States’ AAA long-term credit rating, citing the “steady deterioration in standards of governance over the last 20 years” that have eroded confidence in fiscal management.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Painting With Light: This Garden Shows How It’s Done
description: Innisfree, in Millbrook, N.Y., “doesn’t look like other gardens.” That’s by design.
content: Is it time, gardeners, to really see the light?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Goodman and Andrew Weissmann
title: The New Jack Smith Indictment Is Where Whataboutism Goes to Die
description: To not charge Trump for his election scheme would be the true politicization of justice.
content: Donald Trump has now been indicted three times, accused of crimes occurring before, during and after his presidency. The latest indictment alleges facts from all quarters to prove his criminality: from the vice president to the White House counsel and the heads of the Justice Department, the Department of Homeland Security and the Office of National Intelligence, as well as many others. All are Republican loyalists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Are the Trump Indictments a Turning Point? History Says Not Likely.
description: The latest indictment of former President Donald J. Trump takes the United States to an uncharted place in its history. But other countries’ histories suggest that the prosecution of leaders accused of wrongdoing cannot fix underlying problems.
content: Since the early days of Donald J. Trump’s rise, many observers in the United States and elsewhere have been waiting for the “big one” — the scandal or indictment or gaffe that would end his political career and the chaotic Trump era of American politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: As Objects Fly Onstage, Stars Become Part of the Audience’s Show
description: Disrupting a celebrity may now be the ultimate concert souvenir. No pop star wants to be unsafe, but some are increasingly making themselves part of the crowd.
content: In 2023, it’s tough to know what, exactly, a concert is for anymore. Does someone attend to watch a live musical performance? Or to become part of the show in some way? Or to find a setting that might be optimal to create viral content?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem’ Review: Superfly’s Revenge
description: This time around, the four kung-fu-fighting old masters of the sewers dream of having a normal life with the humans. But not if Ice Cube can help it.
content: There’s a refreshing sense of nostalgia in “Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Madness” — and it doesn’t just have to do with the fact that the eternally youthful ninja turtles have been around since the 1980s, in the form of the original comic book series, as well as TV adaptations, films, toys and video games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: In New York, Covid Cases Are Rising, Slightly, Officials Warn
description: A small uptick in Covid cases has led to more hospitalizations, but the numbers, about 800 statewide, are still far below previous waves.
content: Covid-19 cases and hospitalizations are rising in New York, prompting the state health commissioner on Wednesday to urge New Yorkers to get tested if they have a runny nose, headache or other symptoms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Roger Federer Is Having Fun in Retirement
description: The tennis star and Jonathan Anderson have teamed up with Uniqlo to create a sports-inspired fashion collection.
content: On Wednesday morning a crowd gathered outside the Uniqlo flagship store on Fifth Avenue hoping to catch a glimpse of Roger Federer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Momigliano
title: Six Ways to Avoid the Tourist Logjams in Venice
description: Yes, Venice is so very congested. Yet visiting this unique Italian city doesn’t always require taking what Italians call un bagno di folla — a bath in the crowd.
content: Venice is so congested that it has become the embodiment of overtourism. Each year millions of tourists flock to this small city, home to a dwindling local population of 50,000, and the hordes in St. Mark’s Square are legendary. Yet visiting Venice doesn’t always require taking what Italians call “un bagno di folla” — a bath in the crowd. The city offers plenty of fascinating attractions spared from the congestion, in fact, some of them could use more visitors. Here are some ways travelers can minimize the inconveniences even while visiting the most popular sites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: 100 Today, She Remembers: ‘We Sewed, We Talked’
description: Ruth Taube taught sewing at the Henry Street Settlement on the Lower East Side for more than 60 years.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll meet a woman who taught sewing on the Lower East Side for much of her life — and she is 100 years old today. We’ll also find out why Senator Bob Menendez’s new wife has apparently attracted the attention of federal prosecutors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: A Thief Returned My Stolen Bike. Do I Owe Him a Reward?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether every promise has to be kept.
content: My 25-year-old son was using my mountain bike for his grass-cutting business when it was stolen. He felt bad; I felt mad. I ran an ad: “Mountain bike stolen. $500 reward. No questions asked.” To my surprise, I got a response from someone, and we set a time to meet. Then I became worried that I was being set up to be robbed. So I called my son. Next thing I knew there were six hulking 20-somethings tagging along with me in my minivan. At the agreed-upon meeting spot, the guy appeared with my bike in hand. I got out, then the six big guys got out, and while I’m looking the bike over, they said, in no uncertain terms, that it was not necessary for me to pay for the bike. The guy looked scared, and I wanted things to end safely, so I peeled off half the stack. “How about $250?” The guy took the money and ran off. Should I instead have given him the original amount? Or do I owe him nothing? — Name Withheld
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: For the Court of Public Opinion, Trump Relies on a ‘Whataboutism’ Defense
description: As the former president faces multiple criminal indictments, he and his defenders try to shift attention by pointing to President Biden’s son Hunter.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump now faces 78 felony counts in three different criminal cases, not to mention a slew of civil lawsuits and trials alleging all sorts of wrongdoing. At least in the court of public opinion, though, his defense can be boiled down to three words.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Meta Begins Blocking News in Canada
description: The change came in response to a new law in Canada that requires tech companies to pay news outlets for using their content.
content: Meta, the company behind Facebook and Instagram, has started blocking news articles on its social networking services in Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My New Boyfriend Is a Dud at Buying Gifts. What Can I Do?
description: A reader asks whether she should be more blunt about her wish for birthday and anniversary presents from a man who isn’t the gift-giving type.
content: My boyfriend and I are two weeks away from the first anniversary of our meeting. We both lost longtime spouses within the last five years. I love him, and I believe he loves me, too. We’re talking about moving in together. My disappointment with him involves gift-giving: He doesn’t celebrate special days or want gifts or any acknowledgment. But I love giving and receiving presents! For my birthday, he took me to dinner, but otherwise made little effort. He offered to buy me a gift if I wanted something. (For his birthday, I made a special dinner and some homemade candy.) Also, he’s had some health issues recently that have created extra work for me. I don’t begrudge that, and he seems grateful, but an occasional gift or word of appreciation would be nice. Should I tell him I want a gift for our anniversary?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: This Summer Is Pointing Us Toward Uncharted Territory
description: The climate is playing by a different set of rules now.
content: On the last day of July, Phoenix finally registered a temperature high below 110 degrees Fahrenheit — the first time that had happened in 31 days. The temperature of pavement in the city measured up to 180 degrees, and local burn units are full of patients who simply fell to the ground and were burned, as though Maricopa County’s whole surface were a skillet on the stove. The I.C.U.s are filling up, too, and the region’s iconic saguaro cactuses are crumpling and collapsing in the heat. On the same day last week that President Biden offered only a few meek remarks about extreme heat and just a few million dollars in new funding for heat forecasting, the U.N. secretary general, António Guterres, leaned into a typically vehement formulation. “The era of global warming has ended,” he said. “The era of global boiling has arrived.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: The Knockout-Stage Showdown Between Sweden and the U.S. Is On
description: Sweden and the U.S. teams have history. The Americans have the better of that, but Sweden has been stronger in this tournament.
content: Sweden did what the United States could not: It got the goals it needed, secured the win it wanted, and marched toward the game everyone expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Drew A. Harris
title: Deep Inside Mountains, Work Is Getting Much More Dangerous
description: Cases of severe black lung disease are back to the highest level in decades. It’s totally preventable.
content: As a high school baseball star, Denver Hoskins led Kentucky in home runs and was invited to try out for the Cincinnati Reds. But when his father got sick (and later died) from black lung, a disease caused by inhaling mineral dust, the younger Mr. Hoskins gave up his Division I college scholarship offer to support his family. Following in his father’s footsteps, he went to work as a coal miner. By the age of 44, Mr. Hoskins was diagnosed with his own case of the most severe form of black lung. He now breathes from an oxygen tank at night and watches his son’s batting practice from the sidelines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Maggie Astor and Luke Broadwater
title: From Right-Hand Man to Critical Witness: Pence at Heart of Trump Prosecution
description: Mike Pence is playing an extraordinary role in a historic criminal case against his onetime benefactor and current rival, whose angry supporters once threatened Mr. Pence’s life.
content: Former Vice President Mike Pence’s remarkable transformation from Donald J. Trump’s most loyal lieutenant to an indispensable, if reluctant, witness for his prosecution became clear this week, when he emerged as perhaps the central character in a stinging indictment accusing the former president of a criminal conspiracy to overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: As States Confront a Reading Crisis in Schools, New York Lags Behind
description: Across the nation, state leaders are taking steps to improve reading instruction for struggling students. But in New York, concern has grown: Is too little being done?
content: Miguel and Jessica Millan knew something was wrong: Their 6-year-old son could not read. He could not remember the alphabet. But he was still being passed through grades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: From Jacobites to Populists
description: How the wars of 18th-century Britain foreshadowed the divisions of our times.
content: Drive northward in the United Kingdom, as I did with my family this past month, and beyond a certain latitude it becomes impossible to escape the Jacobites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How to Self-Publish Your E-Book
description: If you have a story you want to share, you can easily publish your work in popular electronic bookstores — and maybe even make a little money.
content: Have you ever dreamed of publishing your own e-book and making it big — like the best-selling authors Colleen Hoover and Andy Weir? Not everyone has such success, but plenty of writers have found an audience online with platforms, like Amazon Kindle Publishing and Barnes & Noble Press, that allow authors to freely upload their books and sell them. While you may not get as much exposure by skipping traditional publishing methods and releasing your book yourself, you do retain more control over your work and royalties, which can be up to 70 percent of the sale price. If you’re inspired, here’s a basic overview of the process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Jason Aldean’s ‘Try That in a Small Town’ Hits No. 1
description: The country star’s song, now a culture war battleground, is his first all-genre chart topper. The K-pop group NewJeans’ new album edged out the “Barbie” soundtrack on the Billboard 200.
content: Last week, Jason Aldean’s song “Try That in a Small Town,” which the country star portrays as a paean to neighborly values but critics have described as a call to racist vigilantism, opened at No. 2 on Billboard’s Hot 100 chart, after its music video became a culture war battleground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Left-Leaning Wisconsin Groups Challenge the State’s Political Maps
description: Democrats in Wisconsin are seeking to capitalize on a newly friendly State Supreme Court after a liberal justice was sworn in this week.
content: A day after a seismic ideological shift on the Wisconsin Supreme Court, a coalition of voting rights groups and left-leaning law firms filed a legal challenge to the state’s legislative districts, arguing that they were unconstitutional gerrymanders and that new maps should be drawn before the 2024 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: American Fugitive Who Faked His Death Can Be Extradited, Scottish Court Rules
description: Nicholas Rossi, who has used several aliases in recent years, has been charged with rape in Utah.
content: Nicholas Rossi, a convicted sex offender who faked his own death and later surfaced in Glasgow, can be extradited to the United States from Scotland to face sexual assault charges in Utah, a court ruled on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Amid Signs of a Covid Uptick, Researchers Brace for the ‘New Normal’
description: Infections remain very low, despite signs of a slight increase. Now, experts are looking for clues to what living with the coronavirus will be like this winter and beyond.
content: Echoing patterns in prior years, coronavirus infections are slowly ticking up in parts of the country, the harbinger of a possible fall and winter wave. But the numbers remain low for now, and are unlikely to reach the horrific highs seen in previous winters, experts said in interviews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: French Journalists Call Off Strike, Failing to Block ‘Far-Right’ Editor
description: Reporters and editors at a leading newspaper, Le Journal du Dimanche, ended a 40-day walkout, but many were expected to resign.
content: Journalists at France’s leading Sunday newspaper announced Tuesday that they were ending one of the longest media strikes in recent French history, but they predicted that dozens might resign to protest the appointment of an editor with a far-right track record as the new editor in chief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Orlando Mayorquin
title: Barbie Hoax Targets Mattel and Fools Some News Outlets
description: The false campaign by environmental activists claimed that the toy giant was launching a new line of decomposable Barbies and would stop using plastic by 2030.
content: Several news organizations fell for an elaborate hoax on Tuesday that claimed that all Mattel toys, including the iconic Barbie doll, would be plastic free by 2030, starting with a new line of decomposable “EcoWarrior” dolls made with organic materials including mushrooms, algae and clay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: As Russia Strikes Ports, Ukraine’s Farmers Scramble to Keep Exporting
description: Their grain and sunflower oil once helped feed the world. Now, even their backup routes to the international market have become targets.
content: Last week, Valentin Pavlenko loaded two trucks with grain from his farm in southern Ukraine. Normally, he sends them two hours east to the deepwater port of Odesa, but this time they headed in the other direction, to the small port of Reni on the Danube River.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Farrell
title: Larry Fink’s Bet on Saudi Oil Money Is Also His Latest E.S.G. Woe
description: Mr. Fink finds himself on the back foot once again, with BlackRock appointing the head of Saudi oil giant Aramco to its board. Analysts say the move is about money, not optics.
content: For years, Larry Fink, the chief executive of the giant asset manager BlackRock, has been broadcasting a message to corporate America: Environmental, social and governance goals should be core to how companies do business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: Donald Trump faces significant new federal charges.
content: Donald Trump was indicted yesterday in connection with his far-reaching efforts to overturn the 2020 election. It is his second federal indictment — the first was related to his handling of national defense documents — and his third overall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Prevost
title: Old Saybrook, Conn.: A Quiet Shoreline Town With Relatively Low Taxes
description: This Middlesex County community was once a place ‘where middle-class people built cottages.’ Now cash buyers are winning bidding wars.
content: Diana and Dan Colcord spent the spring looking for a place to downsize from their large home in Madison, Conn. After a hunt that spanned the Connecticut coastline, from New Haven to Old Lyme, they found the ideal landing place in Old Saybrook, a Middlesex County town at the junction of the Connecticut River and Long Island Sound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randall D. Eliason
title: What Makes Jack Smith’s New Trump Indictment So Smart
description: The strength of the indictment lies as much in what it charges as what it doesn’t charge.
content: This is the indictment that those who were horrified by the events of Jan. 6, 2021, have been waiting for. The catalog of misdeeds that Donald Trump is accused of is extensive, some reflected in other prosecutions over classified documents and hush-money payments or in civil lawsuits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: A Leader of Niger’s Coup Visits Mali, Raising Fears of a Wagner Alliance
description: Several military officials who took power from the president in Niger last week met with the leaders of Mali, where the Kremlin-backed Wagner mercenary group has deployed about 1,500 troops.
content: A week after a military overthrow of Niger’s elected president, a coup leader and other officers flew to neighboring Mali on Wednesday to meet with its rulers, raising concerns that a key Western ally could grow closer to military leaders in Mali who partner with the Kremlin-backed Wagner private military company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Man Kidnapped and Sexually Assaulted Woman, Then Put Her in Cell, F.B.I. Says
description: Negasi Zuberi, 29, of Oregon, has been linked to violent sexual assaults in at least four states, the F.B.I. said. The authorities are investigating whether he could be behind others.
content: An Oregon man posing as an undercover police officer last month kidnapped a woman in Seattle, sexually assaulted her, drove her to his home and locked her in a makeshift cell from which she managed to escape, the F.B.I. said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts
title: Disney District, Now Under DeSantis’s Control, Ends Its D.E.I. Programs
description: The decision by the special district that governs the Walt Disney World Resort aligns with Gov. Ron DeSantis’s efforts to limit D.E.I. measures.
content: The special district that governs the Walt Disney World Resort in Florida announced on Tuesday that it was ending its diversity, equity and inclusion programs, a decision that is firmly in line with Gov. Ron DeSantis’s efforts to limit such measures in areas like higher education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: R.F.K.-Aligned Super PAC Draws Heavily From a Republican Megadonor
description: A super PAC backing Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s bid for the Democratic nomination received $5 million from a major Republican donor who has supported Donald J. Trump in the past.
content: As he cut into steak frites at the recent fund-raiser he hosted for Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s long-shot bid for the Democratic presidential nomination, the financier Omeed Malik surveyed the crowd.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Draw a Bird
source.name: The New York Times

title: The 3 Sites That Will Honor Emmett Till and His Mother
source.name: The New York Times

title: Best Tomato Recipes
source.name: The New York Times

title: Seeing the Light, at Innisfree Garden
description: This landscape, in Millbrook, N.Y., “doesn’t look like other gardens.” That’s by design.
content: This landscape, in Millbrook, N.Y., “doesn’t look like other gardens.” That’s by design.
source.name: The New York Times
